Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my granddaughter’s eyes shining as she announced her acceptance into the college of her dreams. The whole family was gathered, laughter and congratulations filling the room. I knew how much this moment meant to her—and to all of us. My daughter caught my eye, silently urging me to stay a little longer, to be part of this celebration. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart tightened. My volunteer shift at the community center started in twenty minutes. I’d promised the coordinator I’d be there on time, and I prided myself on being reliable. Still, I knew the others could cover for me if I was late, but I hated the idea of letting them down. The weight of both expectations pressed on me—my family’s joy, my commitment to serve. I felt torn, wishing I could be in two places at once, wrestling with the guilt of disappointing someone no matter what I chose.
